Row.Text: [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Iron Fist[ENDCOLOR]: Vassals can no longer rebel or be liberated by other Civilizations. Yields from City-States increased by 25%, Vassals tribute an additional 25% of their yields, and +50% Worker Improvement rate.

Ruling with an iron fist generally means to require absolute control when managing other people, often in the workplace. The saying can also refer to situations such as child-rearing or styles of government. This idiom is often used to describe the actions and practices of managers, parents, or leaders who give their subordinates little if any freedom of choice or input regarding decisions. Reasons for ruling with an iron fist can often depend on individual circumstances, such as inexperienced workers or unruly children. The effectiveness of using total control can also vary, depending on the scope of the management style and the situation.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Universal Healthcare[ENDCOLOR]: Receive a free Hospital in every City. +50 [ICON_CULTURE] when a Citizen is born in any City, scaling with Era.
Earn [ICON_GOLD] Gold, [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, and [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age Points if you kill a unit. +2 [ICON_GREAT_GENERAL] Great General Points from Ceilidh Hall
Receive +10 [ICON_RESEARCH] Science, [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, and [ICON_FOOD] Food when your Borders expand, scaling with Era. +4 [ICON_FOOD] Food from Ceilidh Hall

+1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture for every 10 [ICON_GOLD] Gold per turn, +1 [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age Points for every 5 [ICON_RESEARCH] Science per turn, and +2 [ICON_GOLD] Gold from [ICON_CONNECTED] City Connections. +5 [ICON_GOLD] Gold from Ceilidh Hall

+1 [ICON_FOOD] Food and [ICON_GOLD] Gold from Forests, +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production and [ICON_RESEARCH] Science from Jungles. +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture from Camps. +2 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture from Ceilidh Hall
+3 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, [ICON_RESEARCH] Science, and [ICON_GOLD] Gold in Cities with a Specialist. +3 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production from Ceilidh Hall

+2 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture in every City, +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold and [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production from every Resource connected with a normal Improvement. +5 [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age Points from Ceilidh Hall
+3 [ICON_FOOD] Food, +3 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production, and +4 [ICON_GOLD] Gold in coastal Cities. +2 [ICON_GREAT_ADMIRAL] Great Admiral Points from Ceilidh Hall

+1 [ICON_RESEARCH] Science for every 3 [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizens in a City. +3 [ICON_RESEARCH] Science, [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, and [ICON_GREAT_SCIENTIST] Great Scientist Points in [ICON_CAPITAL] Capital. +5 [ICON_RESEARCH] Science from Ceilidh Hall

+100% increase to [ICON_RANGE_STRENGTH] Ranged Combat Strength, +25% [ICON_FOOD] Growth, and +8 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture when a [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizen is born, scaling with Era. +4 [ICON_PEACE] Faith from Ceilidh Hall

+1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, [ICON_GOLD] Gold, [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production, and [ICON_RESEARCH] Science for every 4 Followers of your Pantheon in owned Cities. +2 [ICON_HAPPINESS_1] Happiness from Ceilidh Hall
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Peace, Land, Bread[ENDCOLOR]: [ICON_HAPPINESS_3] Poverty reduced by 20% and [ICON_FOOD] Growth increased by 20% in all cities.

The phrase 'Peace, Land, Bread,' popularized by Lenin and others during the early days of the Soviet Revolution, highlighted their desire to focus on the needs of the impoverished Russian peasantry. The Bolshevik Initial Decrees of the 1910-20s were announced as soon as the Bolsheviks declared their success in the October Revolution (October 26, 1917). The decrees conformed to the popular Bolshevik slogan "Peace, Bread, and Land", taken up by the masses during the July Days (July 1917), an uprising of workers and military forces.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Arts[ENDCOLOR] converts 20% of [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production of this City into [ICON_CULTURE] Culture.
Investing production in art is a good way to boost your Civilization's cutural output, either to grab that next policy or to stave off a Tourism victory.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Defense[ENDCOLOR] boosts City [ICON_STRENGTH] Defense and increases Hit Point recovery by 10% of the City's [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production.
Investing production in defense is a last-ditch method to stave off your city's conquest by a foreign power.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Farming[ENDCOLOR] converts 20% of [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production of this City into [ICON_FOOD] Food.
Investing production in farming is a good way to boost your City's growth, which can be useful if you are falling behind in technologies, or you simply need bigger cities.
Restricts international travel between Civilizations. Reduces the [ICON_TOURISM] Tourism modifier for all Civilizations by 35%.
Increases international travel between Civilizations. Increases the [ICON_TOURISM] Tourism modifier for all Civilizations by 50%.

Colonia are upgraded versions of the Great Merchant's Towns. In addition to higher yields, Colonia acquire all tiles adjacent to itself when constructed (like the Citadel), and can be constructed on unowned tiles adjacent to owned territory. These abilities allow Venice to claim additional territory in spite of Venice's inability to settle new cities. Colonia also gain additional [ICON_GOLD] Gold and [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production if built on a Road or Railroad that connects two owned Cities[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Receive additional [ICON_GOLD] Gold and [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production (+1 pre-Industrial Era, +2 Industrial Era or later) if a Trade Route, either internal or international, passes over this Colonia.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Stato da Mar or Domini da Mar ("State/Domains of the Sea") was the name given to the Republic of Venice's maritime and overseas colonies (colonia), including Istria, Dalmatia, Albania, Negroponte, the Morea (the "Kingdom of the Morea"), the Aegean islands of the Duchy of the Archipelago, and the islands of Crete (the "Kingdom of Candia") and Cyprus. It was one of the three subdivisions of the Republic of Venice's possessions, the other two being the Dogado, i.e. Venice proper, and the Domini di Terraferma in northern Italy.
